body:
You can!  Send a pull request and I'll merge it!

On Thu, Jun 27, 2013 at 6:44 PM, 时金魁 notifications@github.com wrote:

> [image: qq20130628-2]https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/648508/719692/107b3514-df94-11e2-8417-a0c3192faccb.png

> 
> who can fix it in master branch ?
>

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/twitter/zipkin/issues/268
> .
@bmdhacks @mosesn

[TracingFilter](https://github.com/twitter/finagle/blob/master/finagle-core/src/main/scala/com/twitter/finagle/tracing/TracingFilter.scala) will register a [Tracer](https://github.com/twitter/finagle/blob/master/finagle-core/src/main/scala/com/twitter/finagle/tracing/Tracer.scala) with [Trace](https://github.com/twitter/finagle/blob/master/finagle-core/src/main/scala/com/twitter/finagle/tracing/Trace.scala).
find it. thanks
@franklinhu Have you had the chance to look at this?

I'm hoping to give this issue some love this week.  Franklin and I are on
call last week and next so our time might be a bit restricted until after
the fourth.

On Mon, Jul 1, 2013 at 9:22 AM, Jared Wong notifications@github.com wrote:

> @franklinhu https://github.com/franklinhu Have you had the chance to
> look at this?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/253#issuecomment-20292760
> .
What is the fancy new autoloading?  I'm just curious.

I don't know Zipkin in depth, but it seems as if you might not have the
database set up. Or, you are somehow putting bad data into your database.

Can you ensure that everything is running? The collector, querier and web
applications. As well as your database, usually either cassandra or redis.

Additionally, are you using the collector to store data into the database?
Or rather, how are you storing data into your database?

Best,
Jared

## 

Jared Wong :: jwong@pinterest.com
this is pretty neat!  have you found that hbase is fast enough to keep a fairly snappy web ui?

> this is pretty neat! have you found that hbase is fast enough to keep a fairly snappy web ui?

Yep HBase is happily running as a backend server for lots of different web ui's.  I haven't finished this part yet, but it should be plenty fast enough and scalable.
I changed the hbase version to a released version so it should be good to go on travis-ci now.
@ghelmling you and Chris might be interested :)

Pretty cool, thanks for the pointer!

On Mon, Jul 15, 2013 at 6:12 PM, dvryaboy notifications@github.com wrote:

> @ghelmling https://github.com/ghelmling you and Chris might be
> interested :)
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/274#issuecomment-21015278
> .

I think the Travis CI failure is due to build environment (MiniDFSCluster expects a umask of 022).  Funny enough, I just answered another question on this earlier today: 
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17625938/hbase-minidfscluster-java-fails-in-certain-environments/17665439#17665439

For another project (hRaven), we had to modify the .travis.yml file to ensure umask was set to "022" prior to the test run by adding the line:

```
script: umask 0022 && mvn test
```

> For another project (hRaven), we had to modify the .travis.yml file to ensure umask was set to "022" prior to the test run

Awesome thanks.  That just saved me a whole lot of debugging time. I'll add that in the next push.

So I pushed out more commits.  Mostly this is just so that everyone can see the idea behind how the indexes will look.

I also added some scaladoc comments.  There are still a lot of places that need more (They're coming I promise).

Thanks everyone for all of the reviews already.
I still have this issue, but I don't see the fix got merged as part of a pull request. Was this fixed?
Turns out we don't really need to do this.  It was a good exercise, but not enough benefit.
Also, how hard is it to add Aggregates?
Lastly, please write some unit tests.
I merged this onto master and it looks good.

The latest push runs the web ui and is pretty well complete.

I think there's still a timestamp bug and indexing annotation values.

It'd be nice to get an aggregates store in there too.  I've been going over the code, I'll give you some more review feedback next week.  This looks really good.  We might even try using this at twitter.

> It'd be nice to get an aggregates store in there too.

I'll give that a shot once I have some more tests and a lot more polish on the code.

> I'll give you some more review feedback next week.

Awesome,  thanks for your help.

Yeah, I'm actually fixing up the aggregate store tests anyways, so feel free to wait a bit.
Also, I need to to sit down with Chris Trezzo to learn about hbase schema design to make sure it's good.  Really stoked on this contribution though and I'm chomping to get some more time to help out with it.

Gave some cursory comments, but will sit down and do a more in-depth review in the near future. 
Also, slight style nit: spaces after colons for type declarations

```
myThing: Array[Byte]
```

rather than

```
myThing:Array[Byte]
```

Pushed a new commit that squashed the old ones.  It contains:
- rebase to master.
- Moved to HTablePool so that the usage inside of HBaseTable is a little clearer on why we're doing that.
- Changed annotation index to use annotation values
- Cleaned up most of the source code nits that @franklinhu was talking about.  Thought the test code still could have some.  I'll address that soon.
Pushed aggregates.

I pushed a new version.  The mapping code still has some blocking; keeping some blocking just makes the code much cleaner and allows a fully tail recursive version of the retry loop.  In addition it allows me to completely stay off of all thread executors on cache hits.
Hmmm not sure what's going on I'll try and work out how to fix the tests.  They seem like a test only issue on travis.
I have the same issue

Thanks for the recommendation.  We don't have a ton of manpower to satisfy external requests like this, but I'd love to work with you through the process of submitting a pull request to fix the things you see that are broken.
Added a couple comments on the JS -- mostly nitpicky, in general LGTM.
The path for storage.anormdb should instead be storage/anormdb.
This is fixed now
I'm closing this since we released the SQL support which eliminates all external dependencies.
Zipkin depends on twitter.util.eval which is not supported in scala 2.10.  In order to move to 2.10 we need to change the configuration mechanism away from eval.
nice
Does this incorporate the image links patch recently sent by the guy on HN which moves the images to github CDN?
Yes
Future {} runs the task synchronously, but this does it async, so if you're not Await.resulting on every Future, you could have an ordering issue.
Do we care about ordering of inserts in zipkin?
Thanks! Glad you're enjoying the project.
I think writes are async with Cassandra and Redis so this wouldn't change behavior.
Anyone know if there is some kind of issue with Await.result() on FuturePools? Not sure why the AnormIndexSpec tests are timing out.
I think this [PR](https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/286) fixes it.
The test that failed on jdk6 is just flaky.
lgtm

You may want to rebase this branch against master since the anorm stuff was merged?

Edit: or just send a PR for the changes against the branch this was built on?
Committed [fix](https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/commit/6f7ffec57d03127cfcdb02e64e424563010543ba) to master :)

Thanks! One of those "can't believe I missed that" moments... :)

On the "multiple exit points" question -- guard clauses are the only [recommended use](http://twitter.github.io/effectivescala/#Control%20structures-Returns) of returns, but I have no objection to doing it the more idiomatic way.

@franklinhu this is against master after the anorm commit.

However, I'm getting confused tracking two concurrent but dependent sets of changes with the [async PR](https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/283) and that one is more current so I'm going to close this one.

Per [my comment here](https://github.com/twitter/zipkin/pull/281#issuecomment-21886353) I am getting confused tracking two concurrent but dependent sets of changes to the Anorm module (adding async + transactions and adding aggregates support) so I am closing the other PR and using this one for both since this branch is more current.
Good call!  I'm probably wrong then, since effective scala is generally very good advice.  However, I find that having many different exit points for my functions drives me nuts.
Heads up, I force-pushed so I could rebase to current master since there were merge conflicts.

Note that this is a breaking change -- that is, people who have installed Zipkin and are using the Anorm module already (e.g. with SQLite) will get errors after applying this change because their schema will not match the schema expected after this change. We should probably have a plan for how to approach schema migration.
I'm OK with kicking the migrations can down the road.

Strange that this even compiled before.  I wonder where the return call returned to, since there probably wasn't anything up-stack from that.  Perhaps it just evaporated the thread without fulfilling the promise.
Please rebase and reopen also.
Oh hey, I merged my dependencies work and messed up the interface.  Do you have time to rebase?

Sure.  Here's a rebased version.  It has:
- New dependencies
- New version of HBase
- Better threading
- Un constrained thread creation is a bad idea with the # of qps that hbase can generate :-)
Ok, done reviewing.  Lemme know about my nits, but I'm cool with merging it as-is.

Ok, I think that addresses all of your thoughts.

I added more thread pools so they can spin up faster when load is applied.
Is this good to merge then from your perspective?
Some of the unit tests fail.
Whoops yeah some debugging stuff got left in there.  Lets run this past ci again.
I like this. I think changing the hash works better here than window.history.pushState and friends. LGTM.
Yep ready to go in.
Do you have the finagle ruby gems included in your environment?

I guess the maven repo is down and move to somewhere else according to MK's comment here, anyone knows where the new location is?

https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/travis-ci/zqneGcTEv4g

>  It has been shut down. Since travis-ci.org infrastructure is now U.S.-based, a separate
>  mirror is no longer necessary.
>  -- 
>  MK

I'm working on a fix.  In the meantime, your zipkin build should not fail
it should just complain a lot.

clean.  Or just trying on a different machine.

I met the problem too.  But my Zipkin project worked a few days ago. 

Update: I finally make it work by removing the jars downloaded in the latest 2 days:

```
find ~/.ivy2/cache/com.twitter -type f -mtime -2 -exec rm -rf {} \;
```
Nice catch!

Ship it!

`Ship It!`
Hmm looks like you're right. We're happy to merge pull requests :)
Pretty sure this one is already completed. Other than one location.

It's a pretty big change to work around it, not that I wouldn't welcome a
patch.  Note that this is in no way related to whether Twitter offers ipv6
endpoints to our customers.

notifications@github.comwrote:

> If I'm right host identifier in trace is currently named ipv4 and encoded
> as int32 and used as integer throughout the system (column types, etc).
> This automaticaly disables ipv6 only hosts from being compatible with
> zipkin. Are there any plans or thoughts how one can add such support or
> maybe workaround can be found?

Failure seems un-related.  Seems like someone's maven repo was down.
Thanks for the contribution!
I've got a newer version in a few mins.
I ran into the same issue while testing zipkin (1.1.0 and master) with the sqlite backend. Changing to redis fixed it.

So it looks like this was an oversight in the way that AnormDB joined spans with annotations and binary annotations. I've posted #308, which should fix this issue. @wadey if you try the branch `fix-anorm-span-merging` does it work?

Ship it!
`Ship it!`

It's located here: http://maven.twttr.com/org/apache/thrift/libthrift/
which should be in the repositories listed in the build.  I've seen people have trouble building in China because of the great firewall blocks twitter properties, perhaps that's what you're seeing?

I think that's a known issue.  I haven't had time to look into it.

On Mon, Oct 28, 2013 at 2:34 AM, Linlin Fu notifications@github.com wrote:

> Zipkin runs on cassandra, but cannot find traces with any specified
> annotation. The cassandra is setup with
> zipkin-cassandra/src/schema/cassandra-schema.txt. Should any indexes be
> created?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/twitter/zipkin/issues/310
> .

The root cause is, in cassandra database, AnnotationsIndex stores RowKey with uppercase letters, but ServiceNames, ServiceNameIndex, SpanNames, ServiceSpanNameIndex use only lowercase letters.

There are two solution, one is AnnotationsIndex uses lowercase letters, the other solution is ServiceNames, ServiceNameIndex, SpanNames, ServiceSpanNameIndex NOT convert to lowercase. Which solution is preferred from your perspective? I can make the change and send a pull request.

Apologies for the slow reply on my part. Lowercasing the AnnotationsIndex would be fine by me.

Thanks!

/Johan

On 5 nov 2013, at 00:43, Linlin Fu wrote:

> The root cause is, in cassandra database, AnnotationsIndex stores RowKey with uppercase letters, but ServiceNames, ServiceNameIndex, SpanNames, ServiceSpanNameIndex use only lowercase letters.
> 
> There are two solution, one is AnnotationsIndex uses lowercase letters, the other solution is ServiceNames, ServiceNameIndex, SpanNames, ServiceSpanNameIndex NOT convert to lowercase. Which solution is preferred from your perspective? I can make the change and send a pull request.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.
fixed?
Concur on lowercasing.
